questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is a large vessel vasculitis?
questions.explanation: Giant cell arteritis is a large vessel vasculitis.

questions.question: Question 2: All of the following vasculitides involves veins except?
questions.explanation: Giant cell arteritis does not involve the veins. Vasculitides affecting the veins are as follows: • Leukocytoclastic vasculitis • Behcet disease • Buerger disease (Thrombangiitis obliterans)

questions.question:
Question 3: A 60-year-old man presents with sudden onset blindness. He gives a history of frequent 
headaches along the sides of his scalp. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of giant cell arteritis. 663 
Sold by @itachibot Giant cell / temporal arteritis is a chronic inflammatory disorder of large to small-sized arteries 
that especially affects the temporal arteries. It is seen in people over 50 years of age. It usually 
presents with facial pain or headache along the course of the superficial temporal artery. It can also affect: • Ophthalmic arteries- leading to sudden onset diplopia or blindness • Aorta- leading to giant-cell aortitis • Vertebral arteries A biopsy is needed to confirm the diagnosis. Giant cell arteritis needs to be promptly diagnosed and treated with steroids to prevent 
permanent blindness.

questions.question:
Question 4: An elderly patient presented with temporal headache and jaw claudication. She was 
diagnosed to be a case of Giant cell arteritis. Which of the following statements about giant 
cell arteritis is incorrect?

options.b: A negative biopsy excludes the diagnosis
options.c: The classic lesions are medial granulomas
options.d: Fragmentation is seen in internal elastic lamina

questions.explanation:
A negative biopsy cannot exclude the diagnosis of giant cell arteritis. It is because the lesions are 
focally distributed. A biopsy sample may be taken from the normal part of the artery leading to a 
false-negative report. An adequate biopsy requires at least a 1-cm segment. Biopsy findings: • Giant cell arteritis is primarily medial granulomatous inflammation. • These lesions involve the internal elastic lamina leading to elastic lamina fragmentation. • There is intimal thickening that reduces the luminal diameter. Granulomas with multinucleated giant cells, infiltrate of T cells (CD4+ >CD8+), and 
macrophages. Note : According to the 21st edition of Harrison's Medicine, as involvement of the vessel may be 
segmental, getting a biopsy segment of 3–5 cm together with serial sectioning of biopsy specimens 
would help to increase a positive yield. And Robbin's 10th edition mentions that an adequate 
biopsy requires at least a 1-cm segment. Image: Giant-cell arteritis with intimal thickening and internal elastic lamina fragmentation 664 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 5: A 30-year-old lady presents with weakness of the left upper limb. On examination, the blood 
pressure recorded on the left upper limb was found to be lower than that of the right upper 
limb. Her aortic arch angiogram showed narrowing of the arch of the aorta and subclavian 
artery. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and radiological findings are suggestive of Takayasu arteritis. Takayasu's arteritis is a granulomatous vasculitis affecting medium and large-sized arteries, in this 
case, the aortic arch and its branches. Clinical manifestations include vision disturbances and 
profound weakening of the pulses, especially in the upper extremities. Histopathology: • Irregular thickening of the vessel wall is seen with associated intimal hyperplasia. • Characteristic granulomatous inflammation, with the presence of giant cells and patchy medial 
necrosis. • Disease progression is associated with collagenous scarring and chronic inflammatory infiltrates 
across all layers of the vessel wall. Other options- Option A: Giant cell arteritis (GCA), also known as temporal arteritis, is an inflammation of 
medium and large-sized vessels. It is more common in women and people aged >50 years. The clinical features include headache associated with scalp pain and jaw claudication, fever, 
fatigue, malaise, and weight loss. Half of the patients have temporal artery abnormalities such as 
enlargement, tenderness, nodular swelling, and loss of pulse of the temporal artery, either 
unilateral or bilateral. Gentle pressure on the scalp may elicit focal or generalized tenderness. Though the arch of the aorta may also be involved in giant cell arteritis (known as giant cell 
aortitis), it is seen in people more than 50 years of age. Whereas, Takayasu arteritis is seen more 
commonly in adolescents and young women. Option C: Thromboangitis obliterans, also known as Buerger's disease, is an inflammatory 
occlusive vascular disorder involving medium- and small-sized vessels in the distal extremities. It 
is most frequently seen in male smokers less than 40 years of age. 665 
Sold by @itachibot Option D: Behcet's disease is a neutrophilic vasculitis affecting small- to medium-sized vessels 
that classically presents as a clinical triad of recurrent oral aphthous ulcers, genital ulcers, and 
uveitis. There can also be gastrointestinal and pulmonary manifestations, with disease mortality 
related to severe neurologic involvement or rupture of vascular aneurysms.

questions.question:
Question 6: A young girl with bilaterally unequal pulses is diagnosed with Takayasu Arteritis. Which of 
the following is the most commonly involved site in Takayasu arteritis?
questions.explanation:
The most commonly involved blood vessel in Takayasu arteritis is sublclavian artery. Takayasu arteritis is an inflammatory and stenotic disease of medium and large-sized arteries 
characterized by a strong predilection for the aortic arch and its branches. It is also known 
as aortic arch syndrome. The order of arteries affected in Takayasu arteritis is subclavian artery > common carotid artery 
> abdominal aorta > renal artery > aortic arch = vertebral > coeliac axis > iliac > 
pulmonary > coronary artery. Takayasu arteritis causes irregular thickening of the vessel wall with intimal hyperplasia leading 
to narrowing of the lumen and organ ischemia. It may have various clinical presentations depending on the vessel involved: • Arch of aorta and its branches: • Subclavian artery- leads to weak pulses in the upper extremities. Hence it is also known as 
pulseless disease • Carotid arteries- leads to weak pulses, blindness, neurological deficits • Distal aorta- leads to claudication of the legs • Pulmonary artery- leads to pulmonary hypertension • Coronary arteries- leads to myocardial infarction • Renal arteries- leads to systemic hypertension

questions.question:
Question 7: A young male presents to the emergency room with severe abdominal pain. The small bowel 
is found to have a small infarcted area which is surgically removed. Histopathological 
examination of the biopsy specimen is given below. Which of the following is the most likely 
cause of the small bowel infarction? 657 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and the histopathological findings are suggestive of polyarteritis 
nodosa (PAN). PAN affects small or medium-sized muscular arteries. It typically affects young adults. The patient 
may present with rapidly accelerating hypertension due to renal artery involvement (most 
common) or abdominal pain and bloody stools caused by involvement of gastrointestinal vessels. Option A: Hyperplastic arteriosclerosis is a vascular pathology seen in severe hypertension. Option B: Cystic medial degeneration leads to dissecting aortic aneurysm. Option C: Mönckeberg’s arteriosclerosis does not cause infarction. 666 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following is characteristically spared in polyarteritis nodosa?
questions.explanation:
Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) characteristically spares the pulmonary circulation. PAN is a systemic vasculitis of small or medium-sized muscular arteries. It typically involves the 
renal (most commonly involved) and visceral vessels. It has no association with ANCA, but about 
30% of patients have chronic hepatitis-B.

questions.question:
Question 9: A 3-year-old child was brought to the hospital with complaints of fever, rash and swelling of 
her hands and feet since past 5 days. There is desquamative skin rash, oedema of hands and 
feet, erythema of palms and soles, oral erythema, and cervical lymphadenopathy. What is the 
likely condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Kawasaki disease or mucocutaneous lymph node 
syndrome. Kawasaki disease is an acute febrile illness associated with arteritis of medium to large-sized 
vessels. It is commonly seen in infants and children <4 years of age. Clinical features include: • Fever • Conjunctival and oral erythema • Blistering, edema of hands and feet • Erythema of palms and soles • Desquamative rash • Cervical lymphadenopathy The disease is usually self-limiting. In some cases, the disease may involve coronary artery leading 
to thrombosis and acute myocardial infarction. Intravenous immunoglobulin and aspirin may be 
given to reduce the risk of coronary artery disease.

questions.question:
Question 10: Which of the following antibodies is associated with vasculitis seen in patients with Kawasaki 
disease?
questions.explanation:
Antibodies to endothelial cells are associated with vasculitis in Kawasaki disease. Option A: Immune complex deposition is characteristic of vasculitis due to systemic immunologic 
disorders such as SLE. Option B: ANCA-associated vasculitis is seen in microscopic polyangiitis, Churg–Strauss 
syndrome, and granulomatosis with polyangiitis. Option D: Autoreactive T cells are seen in giant cell arteritis. Reports have been described in children with a multisystem inflammatory condition (MIS-C) 
linked to COVID-19 infection with some features similar to Kawasaki disease and toxic shock 
syndrome. Although shock is rarely associated with Kawasaki disease, many children with the 
inflammatory syndrome related to COVID show signs of shock. 667 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 11: Which of the following is known as mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Kawasaki disease is also known as mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome. Kawasaki disease is an acute febrile illness occurring in children aged 4 years or younger. It is 
usually self- limiting. This vasculitis affects large to medium-sized vessels and even small vessels. It is also known as mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome because it can present with 
non-purulent conjunctivitis, oral erythema, edema of the hands and feet, desquamative rash, and 
cervical lymph node enlargement. It has a predilection for coronary artery involvement and is the leading cause of acquired heart 
disease in children. Untreated patients may develop coronary artery ectasia or aneurysms, leading 
to rupture or thrombosis, myocardial infarction, and sudden death. Espundia is the muco-cutaneous variant of Leishmaniasis

questions.question:
Question 12: A 27-yr-old woman, presented to OPD with complaints of joint pain and photosensitivity. On 
examination, you see a butterfly rash on the face and petechial hemorrhages on the lower 
limbs. On serology ANA, turns out to be positive. Which of the following is the most likely 
cause of vasculitis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus. The vasculitis occurring 
in a patient with systemic lupus erythematosus is due to immune complex deposition. Vasculitis is the inflammation of the vessel wall. The various mechanisms that cause vasculitis are: • Immune-mediated inflammation- Vasculitis caused by immune-mediated inflammation may 
occur due to the following factors: • Immune complex deposition: Seen in systemic immunological disorders like systemic lupus 
erythematosus (SLE) • Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA): Seen in Wegener's granulomatosis, 
Churg–Strauss disease, etc • Anti endothelial cell antibodies: Implicated in Kawasaki disease • Autoreactive T cells • Infectious pathogens- by direct invasion, generating immune complexes or triggering 
cross-reactivity. • Physical or chemical injury- from irradiation, trauma, toxins, etc.

questions.question:
Question 13: A 43 year-old-male patient came to the clinic with complaints of occasional hematuria and 
recurrent upper respiratory tract infections. Examination revealed tiny petechial 659 
Sold by @itachibot hemorrhages over his lower limbs. The patient tests positive for the anti-proteinase-3 
antibody. Which of the following is true about this major antibody?

options.a: It is also known as p-ANCA
options.d: It shows perinuclear staining on immunofluorescence

questions.explanation:
Anti-proteinase-3/PR3-ANCA / c-ANCA is triggered by certain infections as proteinase 3 shares 
similarities with many microbial peptides. This is the major antibody responsible for 
Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA). Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) are a heterogeneous group of autoantibodies 
directed against the constituents of neutrophils or monocytes. Many patients with vasculitis have 
circulating antibodies that react with neutrophil cytoplasmic antigens. The two most important ANCAs related to vasculitis are: 668 
Sold by @itachibot • Anti-proteinase-3/PR3-ANCA/c-ANCA - Directed against PR3 which is a neutrophil azurophilic 
granule constituent. • Anti-myeloperoxidase/MPO-ANCA/p-ANCA - Directed against MPO which is a lysosomal granule 
constituent involved in oxygen free-radical generation. MPO-ANCAs are induced by several 
therapeutic agents, particularly propylthiouracil.

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following is a pauci-immune rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis?
questions.explanation:
Type III or pauci-immune-type of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) may be a 
component of systemic vasculitis such as Wegener granulomatosis or microscopic polyangiitis.

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following statements about microscopic polyangiitis is not true?

options.a: It affects capillaries, small arterioles, and venules
options.c: It is also known as leukocytoclastic vasculitis
options.d: Lesions of different stages of activity coexist in the same vessel

questions.explanation:
All lesions of microscopic polyangiitis tend to be of the same age in any given patient, unlike 
polyarteritis nodosa where all stages of activity from early to late may coexist in different vessels 
or even within the same vessel. Microscopic polyangiitis is a necrotizing vasculitis that affects capillaries, small arterioles, and 
venules. It is associated with MPO-ANCA. It is also called leukocytoclastic vasculitis because of 
apoptotic neutrophils. It may involve the skin, mucous membranes, lungs, brain, heart, gastrointestinal tract, kidneys, 
and muscle. Therefore, the patient may present with hemoptysis, hematuria, proteinuria, bowel 
pain or bleeding, muscle pain or weakness, and palpable cutaneous purpura. Necrotizing 
glomerulonephritis (90% of patients) and pulmonary capillaritis are particularly common.

questions.question:
Question 16: A 21-year-old boy, who is a known case of asthma, presents with wheezing and rhinitis. 
Laboratory results show peripheral eosinophilia and antibodies against neutrophil 
myeloperoxidase. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and the lab findings are suggestive of Churg–Strauss syndrome. Churg-Strauss Syndrome / Allergic granulomatosis and angiitis is a small-vessel necrotizing 
vasculitis classically associated with: • asthma • allergic rhinitis • asymmetric mono neuritis multiplex • lung infiltrates • peripheral hypereosinophilia • extravascular necrotizing granulomata. It is a multisystem disease with cutaneous involvement (palpable purpura), gastrointestinal tract 
bleeding, and renal disease. Eosinophilic infiltrates may also be seen in the myocardium giving 
rise to cardiomyopathy. 669 
Sold by @itachibot p- ANCA (MPO-ANCA) is positive in about 50% of cases. Histological features are similar to those 
observed in polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) or microscopic polyangiitis but characteristically 
accompanied by granulomas and eosinophils. Eosinophilic vasculitis seen in Churg-Strauss syndrome:

questions.question:
Question 17: A 45-year-old man presents with hematuria, intermittent hemoptysis and chronic sinusitis. 
His chest radiograph shows multiple opacities and cavities. Renal biopsy suggests focal 
necrotizing glomerulonephritis. Which of the following is not seen in this condition?

options.a: Necrotizing granulomas of the upper respiratory tract

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of Wegener's granulomatosis. It is associated with 
PR3- ANCA (and not MPO- ANCA) in about 95% of cases. Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis/Wegener granulomatosis is a necrotizing vasculitis characterized 
by a triad of necrotizing inflammation: • Necrotizing granulomas of the upper respiratory tract or the lung • Necrotizing or granulomatous vasculitis affecting small to medium-sized vessels, most 
prominently in the lungs • Focal necrotizing crescentic glomerulonephritis Males are affected more often than females. The most common clinical features include persistent 
pneumonitis with bilateral nodular and cavitary infiltrates, chronic sinusitis, mucosal ulcerations 
of the nasopharynx, and evidence of renal disease. Image: Chest radiograph showing pulmonary granulomatosis 670 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 18: A 15-year old boy comes to the clinic complaining about recurrent painful oral ulcers. He also 
experiences repeated episodes of eye redness and pain which subside with medication. On 
examination, ulcers are seen on his genitals. Which of the following features would you not 
expect to see in this patient?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Behçet disease. Nail fold capillary abnormalities are 
typically seen in systemic sclerosis. Behcet disease is a neutrophilic vasculitis affecting small- to medium-sized vessels that classically 
presents as a clinical triad of recurrent oral aphthous ulcers, genital ulcers, and uveitis. Other skin 
findings include erythema nodosa (red tender nodules on legs) and positive pathergy test 
(pustular reaction 24-48 hrs after sterile needle puncture or normal saline injection). There can also be gastrointestinal and pulmonary manifestations, with disease mortality related to 
severe neurologic involvement or rupture of vascular aneurysms. Dural sinus thrombosis is the 
most common CNS manifestation in children. Pulmonary aneurysms are the most severe feature 
of pediatric BD. It is associated with HLA subtype B51. T helper 17 (Th17) cells play an important contribution in 
the recruitment of neutrophils, which will later infiltrate into the vessel wall.

questions.question:
Question 19: A 5-year-old child presents with colicky abdominal pain and purpuric skin lesions on the 
extensor surfaces of the arms and legs. Urine analysis reveals hematuria and mild 
proteinuria. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
The clinical features and the investigations are suggestive of Henoch-Schonlein purpura. Henoch-Schönlein purpura is a systemic immune disorder, commonly seen in the age group of 
3-8 years. The patient may present with the following clinical features: • Skin lesions- characteristically involve the extensor surfaces of arms and legs, and also the 
buttocks • Abdominal manifestations- include pain, vomiting, and intestinal bleeding. • Renal manifestations- include gross or microscopic hematuria, nephritic or nephrotic syndrome. 
Renal manifestations are more severe in the adults 671 
Sold by @itachibot It is strongly associated with atopy in a few patients, and the onset often follows an upper 
respiratory infection. IgA is deposited in the glomerular mesangium in a distribution similar to 
that of IgA nephropathy.

questions.question: Question 20: Which of the following structures are involved in Buerger's disease?
questions.explanation:
Arteries, veins and nerves can be involved in thrombangiitis obliterans (Buerger's disease). It is a 
vasculitis of small and medium-sized arteries and secondarily extends into contiguous veins and 
nerves. With time, all three structures can be encased in fibrous tissue.

questions.question:
Question 21: A 32-year-old male smoker presents with intermittent claudication and gangrene of the lower 
extremities. Biopsy of the blood vessels supplying this area shows acute and chronic 
inflammation, with luminal thrombosis containing small neutrophilic microabscesses. 
Granulomatous inflammation appears to extend into the contiguous veins and nerves. What 
is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The most likely diagnosis is thromboangiitis obliterans / Buerger disease. It is the segmental, thrombosing, acute and chronic inflammation of medium-sized and small 
arteries. It principally involves the tibial and radial arteries. It is seen in heavy cigarette smokers, usually before the age of 35 years. HLA-A-9 and 
HLA-B-5 associated with a high risk of TAO. The patients present with intermittent claudication, chronic ulcerations of the extremity, and later 
progress to frank gangrene. The microscopy findings include luminal thrombosis (thrombangiitis), 
that is, thrombus containing microabscesses that occlude the lumen (obliterans). They contain 
small microabscesses composed of neutrophils. Berger disease refers to IgA nephropathy. It is seen within 3-5 days of sore throat. It is associated 
with purpuric rash in the lower limbs.

questions.question:
Question 22: Which of the following histologic findings would be most suggestive of Buerger’s disease in a 
patient?
questions.explanation:
Luminal thrombosis containing small microabscesses composed of neutrophils is seen in 
thromboangiitis obliterans or Buerger disease. Option A: Adventitial mononuclear infiltrates with perivascular cuffing of the vasa vasorum has 
been described in Takayasu arteritis. Option B: Fragmented neutrophils undergoing apoptosis infiltrating blood vessels termed 
leukocytoclastic vasculitis are seen in small vessel vasculitis. Option D: Fibrinoid necrosis is seen in immune reactions involving blood vessels seen in 
immunologically mediated vasculitis syndromes. 672 
Sold by @itachibot Vascular Tumors
